page.title: 04WHITELEAF CROSS, CHILTERNS
page.content: From a great distance, the Whiteleaf cross cut into the chalk above the village of Whiteleaf, near Princes Risborough, can be seen across the Vale of Aylesbury. Oddly it is not so easy to see from just below as the trees obscure it. It is one of Southern Englands great chalk figures and it is widely believed to be a pagan symbol which was 'improved' hundreds of years later, perhaps by the monks of Monks Risborough, two miles away. It may have served travellers as a primitive indication of a trackway down through the thick forest of the Chilterns to the Icknield way. To approach the cross from the woodland paths above it suddenly the banches seem to open out and there below the feet, the wide chalk scar reaches breathtakingly downwards.
